{{for|the people|Sirenik Eskimos}} {{Infobox language |name=Sireniki Eskimo |nativename=Сиӷы́ных |pronunciation={{IPA-iu|siˈʁənəx|}} |states=[[Russia]] |region=[[Bering Strait]] region, mixed populations in settlements Sireniki and Imtuk |ethnicity=[[Sirenik Eskimos]] |extinct=1997 |ref=e18 |speakers2=with the death of Valentina Wye |familycolor = Eskimo-Aleut |fam2=Eskimo |fam3=[[Yupik languages|Yupik]]? |iso3=ysr |glotto=sire1246 |glottorefname=Sirenik Yupik |script=Transcribed with Cyrillic in old monographs (extended with diacritics), but new publications may appear also romanised |notice=IPA }}
'''Sirenik Yupik''',<ref>[http://www.language-archives.org/language/ysr OLAC resources in and about the Sirenik Yupik language]</ref> '''Sireniki Yupik'''<ref>[https://gcrc.carleton.ca/confluence/display/ISIUOP/Sireniki+Sea+Ice+Dictionary Sireniki Yupik Sea-Ice Dictionary]</ref> (also '''Old Sirenik''' or '''Vuteen'''), '''Sirenik''', or '''Sirenikskiy''' is an extinct [[Eskimo–Aleut languages|Eskimo–Aleut language]]. It was spoken in and around the village of [[Sireniki]] (Сиреники) in [[Chukotka Peninsula]], [[Chukotka Autonomous Okrug]], [[Russia]]. The [[language shift]] has been a long process, ending in total [[language death]]. In January 1997, the [[terminal speaker|last native speaker]] of the language, a woman named '''Vyjye''' (Valentina Wye) ({{lang-ru|Выйе}}), died.<ref name=VES>[http://www.siberian-studies.org/publications/PDF/bevakhtin.pdf Vakhtin 1998]: 162</ref><ref name=Vakh-Sir>Linguist List's description about [http://linguistlist.org/people/personal/get-personal-page2.cfm?PersonID=5548&RequestTimeout=500 Nikolai Vakhtin]'s book: [http://linguistlist.org/pubs/books/get-book.cfm?BookID=938 ''The Old Sirinek Language: Texts, Lexicon, Grammatical Notes'']. The author's untransliterated (original) name is “[http://www.eu.spb.ru/univ/rector/index.htm Н.Б. Вахтин] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910134859/http://www.eu.spb.ru/univ/rector/index.htm |date=2007-09-10 }}”.</ref><ref name=ssipr>[http://www.nsu.ru/ip/ Support for Siberian Indigenous Peoples Rights (Поддержка прав коренных народов Сибири)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103005547/http://www.nsu.ru/ip/ |date=2007-11-03 }} – see the [http://www.nsu.ru/ip/eskimos.php section on Eskimos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830162420/http://www.nsu.ru/ip/eskimos.php |date=2007-08-30 }}</ref> Ever since that point, the language has been [[Extinct language|extinct]];<ref name=VES/> nowadays, all [[Sirenik Eskimos]] speak [[Siberian Yupik language|Siberian Yupik]] or [[Russian language|Russian]].
Сиӷы́ных {{IPA-iu|siˈʁənəx|}} is the endonym for the eponymous settlement of Sireniki.<ref>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=7}}</ref><ref name=endonyms>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=195}}</ref> The endonym for the people itself is сиӷы́ныгмы̄́ӷий {{IPA|[siˈʁənəɣˈməːʁij]}} "Sirenikites"; the singular form is сиӷы́ныгмы̄́ӷа {{IPA|[siˈʁənəɣˈməːʁa]}}).<ref name=endonyms/><ref>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=31}}</ref>
This article is based on Menovschikov (1964),<ref name=Men-JazSirEsk>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> with cited examples transliterated from Cyrillic transcription to the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]]. [[File:Asian Siberian Yupik Eskimo map.svg|thumbnail|350px|The Yupik settlement of Sireniki (the red and yellow dot)]]
== Classification ==
=== Genealogical ===
==== External ==== Some argue that the Sirenik language is a remnant of a third group of [[Eskimo language]]s, in addition to [[Yupik languages|Yupik]] and [[Inuit languages|Inuit]] groups,<ref name=Vakh-Sir/><ref name=ssipr/><ref name=VE3>[http://www.siberian-studies.org/publications/PDF/bevakhtin.pdf Vakhtin 1998]: 161</ref><ref name=icc-ch-lan>{{cite web |script-title=ru:Языки эскимосов |work=ICC Chukotka |publisher=[[Inuit Circumpolar Council]] |language=Russian |url=http://www.icc.hotbox.ru/yaziki.htm}}</ref><ref name=men3>[http://www.philology.ru/linguistics4/menovshikov-97a.htm Меновщиков 1997]</ref> see online a visual representation by tree and an argumentation based on [[comparative linguistics]].<ref name=tree>Representing genealogical relations of (among others) Eskimo–Aleut languages by tree: [http://www.uaf.edu/anlc/groups/ Alaska Native Languages] (found on the site of [http://www.uaf.edu/anlc/ Alaska Native Language Center])</ref><ref name=complink>[http://www.uaf.edu/anlc/resources/yupik-inuit/ Lawrence Kaplan: Comparative Yupik and Inuit] (found on the site of [http://www.uaf.edu/anlc/ Alaska Native Language Center])</ref> In fact, the exact [[Language family|genealogical classification]] of Sireniki language is not settled yet,<ref name=Vakh-Sir/> and some others regard it belonging to the Yupik branch.<ref name=siryup>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=91176 Ethnologue Report for Eskimo–Aleut]</ref><ref name=kapyup>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000861/086162e.pdf Kaplan 1990]: 136</ref>
Many words are formed from entirely different [[Root (linguistics)|root]]s than in Siberian Yupik.<ref name=diff-root>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=42}}</ref> Also the grammar has several peculiarities compared to other Eskimo languages, and even compared to [[Aleut language|Aleut]]. For example, [[Dual (grammatical number)|dual number]] is not known in Sireniki Eskimo, while most [[Eskimo–Aleut languages|Eskimo–Aleut language]] have dual,<ref name=only2>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=38}}</ref> including even its neighboring [[Siberian Yupik language|Siberian Yupik]] relatives.<ref name=verb2>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=81}}</ref> The peculiarities amounted to mutual unintelligibility with even its nearest language relatives. This forced Sirenik Eskimos to use [[Chukchi language]] as a [[lingua franca]] when speaking with [[Siberian Yupik|neighboring Eskimo peoples]].<ref name=linfranc>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000861/086162e.pdf Menovshchikov 1990]: 70</ref> Thus, any external contacts required using a different language for Sireniki Eskimos: they either resorted to use of lingua franca, or used [[Siberian Yupik language]]s (being definitely a mutually unintelligible, different language for them, not just a dialect of their own).<ref>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|pp=6–7}}</ref> This difference from all their language relatives may be the result of a supposed long isolation from other Eskimo groups:<ref>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1962|p=11}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964|p=9}}</ref> Sireniki Eskimos may have been in contact only with speakers of unrelated languages for many centuries in the past, influenced especially by non-relative Chukchi.<ref name=linfranc/>
==== Internal ====
Although the number of its speakers was very few even at the end of the nineteenth century, the language had at least two [[dialect]]s in the past.<ref name=VES/>
=== Typological ===
As for its [[morphological typology]], it has [[Polysynthetic language|polysynthetic]] and [[Incorporation (linguistics)|incorporative]] features (just like the other Eskimo languages).
== Phonology == {{expand section|date=November 2013}} Some notes (very far from being a complete description): * The [[alveolar lateral approximant]] {{IPA|/l/}} has its voiceless version {{IPA|/l̥/}}, and it can be also palatalized {{IPA|/lʲ̥/}} * [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/ʔ/}}
== Morphology ==
Like all other Eskimo languages, the [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] is rather complex. A description grouped by [[Lexical category|lexical categories]] follows.
=== Nominal and verbal ===
Although morphology will be treated grouped into a nominal and a verbal part, many Eskimo languages show features which “[[Cross-cutting concern|crosscut]]” any such groupings in several aspects: * the [[Ergative–absolutive language|ergative]] structure at verbs is similar to the [[Possession (linguistics)|possessive]] structure at nouns (see section [[#Ergative–absolutive]]); * a physical similarity exists between nominal and verbal personal suffix paradigms, i.e., in most cases, the respective person-number is expressed with the same sequence of phonemes at: ** [[possessive suffix]]es (at nouns) ** verbal suffixes; * nomenverbum-like roots, becoming nominal or verbal only via the suffix they get; * Eskimo texts abound in various kinds of participles (see section [[#Participles]]);
==== Common grammatical categories ====
Some [[Grammatical category|grammatical categories]] (e.g. [[Grammatical person|person]] and [[Grammatical number|number]]) are applicable to both verbal and nominal [[Lexical category|lexical categories]].
Although person and number are expressed in a single suffix, sometimes it can be traced back to consist of a distinct person and a distinct number suffix.<ref name=person-number>Person and number in a single suffix, or in two distinct ones: p. 61 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref>
===== Person =====
[[Inflection|Paradigm]]s can make a distinction in 3rd person for “self”, thus the mere personal suffix (of the verb or noun) can distinguish e.g. ;a nominal example :“He/she takes his/her own dog” versus “He/she takes the dog of another person”. ;a verbal example :“He/she sees himself/herself” versus “He/she sees him/her (another person)”
Thus, it can be translated into English (and some other languages) using [[reflexive pronoun]]. This notion concerns also other concepts in building larger parts of the sentence and the text, see section [[#Usage of third person suffixes]].
===== Number =====
Although other Eskimo languages know more than the familiar two [[grammatical number]]s (by having also [[Dual (grammatical number)|dual]]), Sireniki uses only singular and [[plural]], thus it lacks dual. As mentioned, Sireniki is peculiar in this aspect not only among Eskimo languages, but even in the entire [[Eskimo–Aleut languages|Eskimo–Aleut language family]],<ref name=only2/> even its neighboring [[Siberian Yupik language|Siberian Yupik]] relatives have dual.<ref name=verb2/>
==== Building verbs from nouns ====
Suffix -{{IPA|/ɕuɣɨn/}}- meaning “to be similar to sth”:
{| border=1 ! Root ! Becomes verbal by suffix<ref name=similar>Suffix -{{IPA|/ɕuɣɨn/}}- meaning “to be similar to sth”: p. 66 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> ! Indicative mood, singular 3rd person |- | {{IPA|/mɨtɨχlʲ̥ux/}} | {{IPA|/mɨtɨχlʲ̥ux-'''ɕuɣɨn'''/}}- | {{IPA|/mɨtɨχlʲ̥ux-'''ɕuɣɨn'''-tɨ-χ/}} |- | raven | to be '''similar''' to a raven | he/she is '''similar''' to a raven |}
===== Predicative form of a noun =====
Predicative form of a noun can be built using suffix -{{IPA|/t͡ʃ ɨ/}}-:<ref name=predform>Predicative form of a noun (suffix -{{IPA|/t͡ʃ ɨ/}}-): p. 66–67 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref>
{| border=1 ! rowspan=2 | Root ! rowspan=2 | Predicative form ! colspan=2 | Examples |- ! Singular 2nd person ! Singular 3rd person |- | {{IPA|/juɣ/}} | {{IPA|/juɣɨ t͡ʃ ɨ/}}- | {{IPA|/juɣɨ t͡ʃ ɨtɨn/}} | {{IPA|/juɣɨ t͡ʃ ɨχ/}} |- | man | to be a man | you are a man | he/she is a man |}
===== Verbs built from [[toponym]]s =====
* {{IPA|/imtuk/}} (a [[Toponymy|toponym]]: Imtuk) * {{IPA|/imtux-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-ŋ/}} (I travel to Imtuk.)<ref name=topnymverb>Verbs built from [[Toponymy|toponym]]s: p. 67 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref>
=== Nominal lexical categories ===
==== Grammatical categories ====
Not only the [[Declension|grammatical case]]s of nouns are marked by suffixes, but also the person of possessor (use of possessive pronouns in English) can be expressed by [[agglutination]].
{| border=1 align=center |+ Excerpt from cases and personal possessive form of {{IPA|/taŋaχ/}} (child)<ref name=persposs>Personal possessive form: p. 44–45 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> | ! Sing 1st person ! Sing 2nd person |- ! [[Absolutive case|Absolutive]] | {{IPA|/taŋaqa/}} (my child) | {{IPA|/taŋaʁɨn/}} (your child) |- ! [[Ablative case|Ablative]] / [[Instrumental case|Instrumental]] | {{IPA|/taŋamnɨŋ/}} (from my child) | {{IPA|/taŋaχpɨnɨŋ/}} (from your child) |- ! [[Dative case|Dative]] / [[lative case|lative]] | {{IPA|/taŋamnu/}} (to my child) | {{IPA|/taŋaχpɨnu/}} (to your child) |- ! [[Locative case|Locative]] | {{IPA|/taŋamni/}} (at my child) | {{IPA|/taŋaχpɨni/}} (at your child) |- ! [[Equative case|Equative]] (comparative) | {{IPA|/taŋamtɨn/}} (like my child) | {{IPA|/taŋaχpɨtɨn/}} (like your child) |} It is just an excerpt for illustration: not all cases are shown, Sirenik language has more grammatical cases. The table illustrates also why Sirenik language is treated as [[Agglutination|agglutinative]] (rather than [[Fusional language|fusional]]).
There is no [[grammatical gender]] (or gender-like [[noun class]] system).
===== Case ===== Sireniki is an [[absolutive–ergative language]].
Cases (listed using Menovščikov's numbering): # [[Absolutive case|Absolutive]] # Relative case, playing the role of both [[genitive case]] and [[ergative case]]. # [[Ablative case|Ablative]] / [[Instrumental case|instrumental]], used also in [[Accusative case|accusative]] structures. # [[Dative case|Dative]] / [[Lative case|lative]] # [[Locative case|Locative]] # [[Vialis case]], see also [[prosecutive case]], and [[List of grammatical cases#Motion via|"motion via"]] # [[Equative case|Equative]] (comparative)
To see why a single case can play such distinct roles at all, read [[morphosyntactic alignment]], and also [[List of grammatical cases#Morphosyntactic alignment|a short table about it]].
Some finer [[grammatical function]]s are expressed using [[postposition]]s. Most of them are built as a combinations of cases * lative or locative or ablative * combined with relative (used as genitive) in a similar way as we use expressions like "on top of" in English.
=== Verbal lexical categories === Also at verbs, the morphology is very rich. Suffixes can express [[grammatical mood]]s of the verb (e.g. [[Imperative mood|imperative]], [[Interrogative mood|interrogative]], [[Optative mood|optative]]), and also negation, [[Grammatical tense|tense]], [[Grammatical aspect|aspect]], the [[Grammatical person|person]] of subject and object. Some examples (far from being comprehensive):
{| border=1 ! rowspan=3 | Phonology ! rowspan=3 | Meaning ! colspan=4 | Grammatical notes |- ! colspan=2 | Person, number of ! rowspan=2 | [[Grammatical mood|Mood]] ! rowspan=2 | Others |- ! subject ! object |- | {{IPA|/aʁaʁɨ-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-mkɨn/}} | I lead you | Singular 1st person | Singular 2nd person | Indicative | |- | {{IPA|/aʁaʁɨ-ɕuk-ɨ-mɕi/}} | Let me lead you | Singular 1st person | Singular 2nd person | Imperative<ref name=imp>Imperative: p. 86 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> | |- | {{IPA|/nɨŋɨ-sɨɣɨŋ-sɨn/}} | Don't you see me? | Singular 2nd person | Singular 1st person | [[Interrogative]] | Negative polarity<ref name=neg>Negation form of a verb: p. 89 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> |}
The rich set of [[morpheme]]s makes it possible to build huge verbs whose meaning could be expressed (in most of widely known languages) as whole sentences (consisting of more words) . Sireniki – like the other Eskimo languages – has [[Polysynthetic language|polysynthetic]] and [[Incorporation (linguistics)|incorporative]] features, in many forms, among others [[polypersonal agreement]].
==== Grammatical categories ====
The [[Polysynthetic language|polysynthetic]] and [[Incorporation (linguistics)|incorporative]] features mentioned above manifest themselves in most of the ways Sirenik language can express [[Grammatical category|grammatical categories]].
===== Transitivity =====
For background, see [[Transitivity (grammatical category)|transitivity]]. (Remember also section [[#Ergative–absolutive]].)
See also.<ref name=TerShir-ISP>Nicole Tersis and Shirley Carter-Thomas: [http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/resolve?doi=10.1086/501248&erFrom=635141024526605061Guest Integrating Syntax and Pragmatics: Word Order and Transitivity Variations in Tunumiisut]. It treats an Inuit language: not Sireniki, but a relative. Availability: on paper and restricted online.</ref>
===== Polarity =====
Even the [[grammatical polarity]] can be expressed by adding a suffix to the verb.
An example for negative polarity: the negation form of the verb {{IPA|/aʁaʁ-/}} (to go): * {{IPA|/juɣ aʁaχ-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-χ/}} (the man walks) * {{IPA|/juɣ aʁaʁ-ɨ-tɨ-χ/}} (the man does not walk)<ref name=neg/>
===== Aspect =====
[[Grammatical aspect]]: * {{IPA|/aftalʁa-'''qɨstaχ'''-/}} (to work '''slowly''') and {{IPA|/aftalʁa-'''qɨstaχ'''-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-χ/}} (he works '''slowly'''),<ref name=aspslow>Suffix -{{IPA|/qɨstaχ-/}} for slow action [[Grammatical aspect|aspect]]: p. 72 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> from {{IPA|/aftalʁa-/}} (to work)
===== Modality =====
Also [[linguistic modality]] can be expressed by suffixes. [[Modal verb]]s like "want to", "wish to" etc. do not even exist:<ref name=mod>Modality: p. 68 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> {| border=1 align=center |+Suffix -jux- (to want to): | {{IPA|/aftalʁaχ-/}} (to work) | {{IPA|/aftalʁaʁ-'''jux'''-/}} (to '''want''' to work)<ref name=mod/> |- | {{IPA|/aftalʁaχ-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-ŋ/}} (I work)<ref name=present>Present tense: p. 61 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> | {{IPA|/aftalʁaʁ-'''jux'''-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-ŋ/}} (I '''want''' to work)<ref name=mod/> |} The table illustrates also why Sirenik is treated as [[Agglutination|agglutinative]] (rather than [[Fusional language|fusional]]).
===== Voice =====
Four [[grammatical voice]]s are mentioned in:<ref name=voice>[[Grammatical voice]]s: p. 78–80 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> ;active ;passive :confer {{IPA|-/ɕi/-}} that variant of [[Siberian Yupik]] which is spoken by Ungazigmit<ref>Рубцова 1954, pp. 121–123</ref> ;middle (medial) ;causative :{{IPA|/malikam aʁaχ-'''ɕaχ'''-tɨqɨχ-tɨ-ʁa kɨtuɣi qurŋi-nu/}} (Malika '''make'''s Kitugi go to the reindeer.)<ref name=voice/> all of them are expressed by agglutination, thus, no separate words are required.
=== Participles ===<!-- This section is linked from [[Participle]] -->
A distinction between two kinds of [[participle]]s ([[adverbial participle]] and [[adjectival participle]]) makes sense in Sireniki (just like in [[Hungarian grammar|Hungarian]], see [[:hu:Határozói igenév|határozói igenév]] and [[:hu:Melléknévi igenév|melléknévi igenév]] for detailed description of these concepts; or in [[Russian grammar|Russian]], see [[:ru:Деепричастие|деепричастие]] and [[:ru:Причастие (часть речи)|причастие]]).
Sireniki has many kinds of participles in both categories. In the following, they will be listed, grouped by the relation between the “dependent action” and “main action” (or by other meanings beyond this, e.g. [[Linguistic modality|modality]]) – following the terminology of <ref name=Men-JazSirEsk/>. A sentence with a participle can be imagined as simulating a subordinating [[compound sentence (linguistics)|compound sentence]] where the action described in the [[dependent clause]] relates somehow to the action described in the [[Independent clause|main clause]]. In English, an [[adverbial clause]] may express [[Adverbial clause#Kinds of adverbial clauses|reason, purpose, condition, succession etc.]], and a [[relative clause]] can express many meanings, too.
In an analogous way, in Sireniki Eskimo language, the "dependent action" (expressed by the adverbial participle in the sentence element called [[adverbial]], or expressed by the adjectival participle in the sentence element called attribute) relates somehow to the “main action” (expressed by the verb in the sentence element called [[Predicate (grammar)|predicate]]), and the participles will be listed below grouped by this relation (or by other meanings beyond this, e.g. [[Linguistic modality|modality]]).
==== Adverbial participles ====
They can be translated into English e.g. by using an appropriate [[adverbial clause]]. There are many of them, with various meanings.
An interesting feature: they can have person and number. The person of the dependent action need not coincide with that of the main action. An example (meant in the British English usage of “shall / should” in the 1st person: here, conveying only conditional, but no necessity or morality):
{| border=1 |+ “I” versus “we” | {{IPA|/mɨŋa iŋɨjaxtɨk-t͡ʃɨ-ʁɨjɨqɨɣɨ-ma, ajvɨʁaʁjuʁuχtɨki/}} |- | If ''I'' were a marksman, ''we'' should kill walrus |}
Another example (with a different adverbial participle): {| border=1 |+ “he/she” versus “they” | {{IPA|/ɨ̆ l̥tɨʁinɨq ȷ̊an, upʃuχtɨqɨχtɨʁij/}} |- | when ''he/she'' sings, ''they'' keep frightening him/her |}
They will be discussed in more details below.
===== Reason, purpose or circumstance of action =====
An adverbial participle “explaining reason, purpose or circumstance of action” is expressed by suffix -{{IPA|/lɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/ l̥ɨ/}}- (followed by appropriate person-number suffix). Examples:<ref name=cagoco>Adverbial participle -{{IPA|/lɨ/}}- / - {{IPA|/l̥ɨ/}}- “explaining reason, purpose or circumstance of action”: pp. 90–91 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref>
{| border=1 ! rowspan=2 | Persons ! colspan=2 | Sentence |- ! Adverbial participle ! Verb |- | rowspan=2 | 1st—1st | {{IPA|/jɨfkɨ-lɨ-ma}} | {{IPA|itχɨ-mɨ-t͡ʃɨ-ŋ/}} |- | (I) having stood up | I went in |- | rowspan=2 | 3rd—3rd | {{IPA|/jɨfkɨ-lɨ-mi}} | {{IPA|itχɨ-mɨ-tɨ-χ/}} |- | (he/she) having stood up | he/she went in |}
Another example,<ref name=wenttoexamine>Adverbial participle -{{IPA|/lɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/ l̥ɨ/}}- “explaining reason, purpose or circumstance of action” exemplified in another usage: p. 99 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> with a somewhat different usage: {| border=1 ! Adverbial participle ! Verb |- | {{IPA|/nɨŋitu l̥ɨku}} | {{IPA|pɨjɨkɨŋa/}} |- | To examine him/her<sub>2</sub> (another being) | he/she<sub>1</sub> went |}
===== Dependent action ends just before main action begins =====
Using the adverbial participle -{{IPA|/ja/}}- / -{{IPA|/ɕa/}}-, the dependent action (expressed by the adverbial participle in the [[sentence element]] called [[adverbial]]) finishes just before the main action (expressed by the verb in the sentence element called [[Predicate (grammar)|predicate]]) begins.<ref name=endjustbeg>Adverbial participle -{{IPA|/ja/}}- / -{{IPA|/ɕa/}}- (dependent action ends just before main action begins): pp. 91–92 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref>
===== Dependent action begins before main action, but they continue together till end =====
It can be expressed by suffix -{{IPA|/inɨq ȷ̊a/}}-.<ref name=endjustbeg>Adverbial participle -{{IPA|/ja/}}- / -{{IPA|/ɕa/}}- (dependent action ends just before main action begins): p. 92 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> Examples:
{| border=1 | {{IPA|/nukɨ l̥piɣt͡ʃɨʁaʁɨm aninɨq ȷ̊ami qamt͡ʃɨni tiɣɨmɨra(x)/}} |- | the boy, going out <nowiki>[of the house]</nowiki>, took his <nowiki>[own]</nowiki> sledge <nowiki>[with himself]</nowiki>) |} where {| border= 1 |+ {{IPA|/nukɨ l̥piɣt͡ʃɨʁaʁɨm/}} ! Phonology ! Syntax ! Semantics |- | {{IPA|/nuˈkɨ l̥piɣˈt͡ʃɨʁaχ/}} | noun | boy |- | -{{IPA|/ɨm/}} | case suffix | relative case |}
{| border=1 |+ {{IPA|/aninɨq ȷ̊ami/}} ! Phonology ! Syntax ! Semantics |- | {{IPA|/an/}}- | root | go out |- | -{{IPA|/inɨq ȷ̊a/}}- | the suffix of the adverbial participle | dependent action begins before main action, but they continue together till end |- | -{{IPA|/mi/}} | person-number suffix for adverbial participle in intransitive conjugation<ref name=intradvpart>Intransitive conjugation of adverbial participles -{{IPA|/ja/}}- / -{{IPA|/ɕa/}}-, -{{IPA|/inɨq ȷ̊a/}}-: p. 91 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> | subject of singular 3rd person |}
{| border=1 |+ {{IPA|/qamt͡ʃɨni/}} ! Phonology ! Syntax ! Semantics |- | {{IPA|/ˈqamt͡ʃa/}} | noun | sled |- | -{{IPA|/ni/}} | possessive suffix for nouns | singular, 3rd person, self: “his/her own …” |}
{| border=1 |+ {{IPA|/tiɣɨmɨra(x)/}} ! Phonology ! Syntax ! Semantics |- | {{IPA|/tɨɣɨˈraχ/}} | verb | he/she took something |- | -{{IPA|/mɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/ɨmɨ/}}- | tense suffix | past tense (not the “near past” one) |}
Another example: {| border=1 | {{IPA|/ɨ̆ l̥tɨʁinɨq ȷ̊an, upʃuχtɨqɨχtɨʁij/}} |- | when he/she sings, they keep frightening him/her |}
===== Conditional =====
Dependent action is conditional: it does not takes place, although it would (either really, or provided that some—maybe irreal—conditions would hold). Confer also [[conditional sentence]].
Sireniki Eskimo has several adverbial participles to express that.<ref name=condadvpart>Adverbial participles conveying conditional dependent action: pp. 92–93 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> We can distinguish them according to the concerned condition (conveyed by the dependent action): it may be * either real (possible to take place in the future) * or irreal (it would take place only if some other irreal condition would hold)
====== Real ======
It is expressed with suffix -{{IPA|/qɨɣɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/kɨɣɨ/}}-, let us see e.g. a paradigm beginning with {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-ma/}} (if I get off / depart); {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-pi/}} (if you get off / depart):
{| border=1 ! rowspan=2 colspan=2 | ! colspan=2 | Number |- ! Singular ! Plural |- ! rowspan=3 | Person ! 1st | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-ma/}} | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-mta/}} |- ! 2nd | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-pi/}} | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-pɨɕi/}} |- ! 3rd | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-mi/}} | {{IPA|/aʁa-qɨɣɨ-mɨŋ/}} |}
====== Irreal ====== Confer [[counterfactual conditional]]. Sireniki can compress it into an adverbial participle: it is expressed with suffix -{{IPA|/ɣɨjɨqɨɣɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/majɨqɨɣɨ/}}-.
The dependent action is expressed with an adverbial participle. The main action is conveyed by the verb. If also the main action is conditional (a typical usage), than it can be expressed with a verb of conditional mood. The persons need not coincide.
An example (meant in the British English usage of “shall / should” in the 1st person: here, conveying only conditional, but no necessity or morality):
{| border=1 | {{IPA|/mɨŋa iŋɨjaxtɨk-t͡ʃɨ-ʁɨjɨqɨɣɨ-ma, ajvɨʁaʁjuʁuχtɨki/}} |- | If I were a marksman, we should kill walrus. |}
The example in details:
Dependent action: {| border=1 |+ {{IPA|/iŋɨjaxtɨk-t͡ʃɨ-ʁɨjɨqɨɣɨ-ma/}} (if I were a marksman) ! Phonology ! Syntax ! Semantics |- | {{IPA|/iŋˈɨːjaxta/}} | noun | marksman |- | -{{IPA|/t͡ʃɨ/}}- | suffix [[#Building verbs from nouns|building a verb out of a noun]] | [[#Predicative form of a noun|predicative form]] of noun |- | -{{IPA|/ɣɨjɨqɨɣɨ/}}- / -{{IPA|/majɨqɨɣɨ/}}- | the suffix of the adverbial participle | irreal condition |- | -{{IPA|/ma/}} | person-number suffix for adverbial participles in the intransitive conjugation | subject 1st person |}
==== Adjectival participles ====
There are more kinds of them. * {{IPA|/imtuɡnu aʁaqt͡ʃɨχ qɨmɨ l̥ɨʁaχ utɨχt͡ʃɨmɨt͡ʃɨχ/}} (The sledge [that went to Imtuk] returned.) * {{IPA|/juɣ qavɨ l̥ɨʁɨχ nɨŋɨsɨmɨrɨqa/}} (I saw [perceived] a sleeping man.) They can be used not only in attributive role (as in the above examples), but also in predicative role:<ref name=rolesadjpart>Attribute versus predicative usage of adjectival participles: p. 95 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> * {{IPA|/juɣ qavɨ l̥ɨʁɨχ/}} (The man is sleeping.)
===== Modality =====
Adjectival participle -{{IPA|/kajux/}} / -{{IPA|/qajux/}} conveys a meaning related rather to [[Linguistic modality|modality]] (than to the relation of dependent action and main action). It conveys meaning “able to”.<ref name=adjpart-able>Adjectival participle -{{IPA|/kajux/}} / -{{IPA|/qajux/}} (able to): p. 97 of {{harvnb|Меновщиков|1964}}</ref> * {{IPA|/taŋaʁaχ pijɨ'''kajux''' pijɨxtɨqɨχtɨχ  l̥mɨnɨŋ/}} (A child who is able to walk moves around spontaneously)
== Syntax ==
=== Ergative–absolutive ===
Sireniki is (just like many Eskimo languages) an [[ergative–absolutive language]]. For English-language materials treating this feature of Sireniki, see Vakhtin's book,<ref name=Vakh-Sir/> or see online a paper treating a relative Eskimo language.<ref name=Sch-WGAP>Bodil Kappel Schmidt: [http://www.ub.uit.no/baser/nordlyd/include/getdoc.php?id=106&article=12&mode=pdf West Greenlandic antipassive]</ref>
=== Usage of third person suffixes ===
Although the below examples are taken from [[Inuit]] Eskimo languages ([[Kalaallisut language|Kalaallisut]]), but e.g. Sireniki's distinguishing between two kinds of 3rd person suffixes can be concerned, too (remember section [[#Person]] above: there is a distinct reflexive (“own”-like) and an “another person”-like 3rd person suffix).
==== Topic–comment ====
For a detailed theoretical treatment concerning the notions of [[Topic (linguistics)|topic]] (and [[Anaphora (linguistics)|anaphora]], and [[Binding (linguistics)|binding]]), with Eskimo-related examples, see online [http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~mbittner/ Maria Bittner]'s works, especially.<ref name=Bit-WO>[http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~mbittner/pdf%20files%20for%20web/bittner%2003_cls.pdf Word Order and Incremental Update]. See also the author's Kalaallisut materials.</ref>
==== Obviation ====
For a treatment of ''obviation'' in (among others) Eskimo languages, see online<ref name=obv>Maria Bittner and Ken Hale: [http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~mbittner/pdf%20files%20for%20web/bittner%20&%20hale%2093.pdf Comparative notes on ergative case systems]. Rutgers and MIT. 1993.</ref> and in more details (also online)<ref name=BittHal-Erg>Maria Bittner and Ken HaleErgativity: [http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~mbittner/pdf%20files%20for%20web/bittner%20&%20hale%2096b.pdf Towards a theory of a heterogenous class]</ref> from the same authors.
=== Word order ===

revision.text:
'''Valaikaapu''' <ref>{{cite book|last=Stone|first=ed.: Helaine Selin ; co-ed. Pamela K.|title=Childbirth across cultures : ideas and practices of pregnancy, childbirth and the postpartum|year=2009|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht [etc.]|isbn=9048125987|pages=100|url=https://www.amazon.com/Childbirth-Across-Cultures-Non-Western-ebook/dp/B003RISTJ6}}</ref> [வளைகாப்பு] is a ceremony and celebration held by Hindu, Muslim and Christian women in [[Tamil Nadu]], and [[Telangana]] meant to bless a pregnant woman, celebrate her fertility, and ensure a safe birth. It is hosted by the pregnant woman's mother and father during the third trimester of the pregnancy.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stone|first=ed.: Helaine Selin ; co-ed. Pamela K.|title=Childbirth across cultures : ideas and practices of pregnancy, childbirth and the postpartum|year=2009|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht [etc.]|isbn=9048125987|pages=100|url=https://www.amazon.com/Childbirth-Across-Cultures-Non-Western-ebook/dp/B003RISTJ6}}</ref> . Hindu women will be worn with bangles in both the hands in odd numbers. It is believed that the bangle sound induces the child's senses<ref>{{cite book|last=Stone|first=ed.: Helaine Selin ; co-ed. Pamela K.|title=Childbirth across cultures : ideas and practices of pregnancy, childbirth and the postpartum|year=2009|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht [etc.]|isbn=9048125987|pages=102|url=https://www.amazon.com/Childbirth-Across-Cultures-Non-Western-ebook/dp/B003RISTJ6}}</ref> The women put red and green glass bangles on the mother-to-be’s wrists, sing hymns and songs and put vermilion on her forehead. The woman then rests at her parents' home for the final weeks of her pregnancy.
The purpose of the ceremony is to honour and protect the pregnant woman, who is seen as vulnerable to the evil eye, malign spirits and ghosts, and to ensure the birth of a healthy child. Valaikaapu was originally a simple ceremony, mainly limited to the exchange of bangles. But as valaikaapu became more widely practiced, it grew more lavish, and since the 1980s has been celebrated by most, according to anthropologists who have studied the practice, with "magnificence and sumptuousness," with gifts including jewellery, saris, household appliances, mobile phones and gold ornaments.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Petitet|first=Pascale Hancart|author2=Pragathi Vellore |title=Ethnographical views on valaikappu. A pregnancy rite in Tamil Nadu|journal=Indian Anthropologist|year=2007|volume=37|issue=1|pages=117–145|url=http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/34/71/68/PDF/valaikkappu.ang.pdf|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref>
Similar ceremonies are held in other parts of India and in Pakistan, including among [[Bengali people|Bengali]] women, [[Maharashtrians|Marathi]] and [[Konkani]] women (who call the ceremony [[Dohale Jevan]] [डोहाळे जेवण]), [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] women (who call it [[Godh-Bharai]]), [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]] women, and [[Marwari people|Marwari]] women.<ref>{{cite book|last=Soundar|first=Chitra|title=Gateway to Indian culture|year=2003|publisher=Asiapac Books|location=Singapore|isbn=9812293272|pages=70|url=https://www.amazon.com/Gateway-indian-Culture-Chitra-Soundar/dp/9812293272/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1343835600&sr=1-1&keywords=9812293272|edition=2nd ed. (revised).}}</ref>
{{Commons category|Valaikaapu}}
==Gallery== <gallery> Valaikaappu.jpg|Valaikaapu ceremony ValaiKaappu.jpg|Bangles on ValaiKaappu Valaikaappu 002.jpg|Bangles on ValaiKaappu </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{more footnotes|date=August 2014}}}} The '''Yngsjö murder''' occurred on 28 March 1889 in [[Yngsjö]], [[Sweden]]. Hanna Johansdotter (born 1867) was murdered by her husband Per Nilsson and his mother Anna Månsdotter (born 28 December 1841), who became known as '''''Yngsjömörderskan''''' (in English: The Yngsjö Murderess). Both were sentenced to death for the murder, and Månsdotter became the last woman in Sweden to be executed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://monaper.se/Yngsjomordet.htm |title=Yngsjömordet |first= |last= |work=monaper.se |year= |accessdate=28 March 2011 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812020556/http://www.monaper.se/Yngsjomordet.htm |archivedate=August 12, 2010 }}</ref>
== Circumstances == {{refimprove section|date=August 2014}} The circumstances of the murder are not entirely clear, as both Månsdotter and her son gave several different explanations for it. In later years it has been suggested that she carried out the murder alone. During the trial it came to light that she had a sexual relationship with her son, and that this eventually led to the murder. It is believed that she murdered her daughter-in-law because of jealousy, and that she did this with her son's consent.
Anna Månsdotter had married Nils Nilsson, 13 years her elder, expecting a wealthy future, but they had become poor and afflicted with debts. She had three children, of which only one, her son Per, lived to adulthood. Anna's spouse Nils died in 1883. She had arranged the marriage between Per and Hanna Johansdotter, possibly as a way to prevent the spread of rumours about incest. The marriage was not a happy one. Anna did not move in with her own mother, which had been the initial plan, and Hanna complained to her father that her mother-in-law was the cause of her unhappy marriage. One suggestion is that Hanna had discovered the sexual relationship between her husband and his mother, and that they together murdered her to prevent her from being able to tell anyone. One of many summaries given of the murder was that they beat her with a piece of wood, after which Anna strangled her. They then dressed her and placed her as if she had fallen down the stairs.
Månsdotter was executed on the district jail grounds in [[Kristianstad]] on 7 August 1890 by executioner [[Albert Gustaf Dahlman]]. Per Nilsson was pardoned from his death sentence and was instead sentenced to hard labour for the rest of his life. He was however released in 1913 and died of [[tuberculosis]] in 1918.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buf.kristianstad.se/trolle/3_5/Yngsjomordet.html |title=Yngsjömordet |first= |last= |work=Buf.kristianstad.se |year=2005 |accessdate=28 March 2011 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328125638/http://www.buf.kristianstad.se/trolle/3_5/Yngsjomordet.html |archivedate=March 28, 2010 }}</ref>
== In media == The Yngsjö Murder has been portrayed in numerous movies and books over the years:
*In 1966 a full-length feature film, ''Yngsjömordet'', was made about the murder, directed by [[Arne Mattsson]], with [[Gösta Ekman]] (as Per Nilsson), [[Gunnel Lindblom]] (as Anna Månsdotter) and [[Christina Schollin]] (as Hanna Johansdotter).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfi.se/sv/svensk-filmdatabas/Item/?itemid=4742&type=MOVIE&iv=Story |title=Yngsjömordet (1966) |publisher=[[Swedish Film Database]] |accessdate=28 March 2011 |language=Swedish}}</ref> *In 1986 a part of the mini-series, ''Skånska mord'', also entitled "Yngsjömordet", was made, directed by [[Richard Hobert]].
== Gallery == <gallery> Image:Anna Månsdotter.jpg|The mother, Anna Månsdotter. Image:Per Nilsson (1862-1918).jpg|The son, Per Nilsson. Image:Hanna Johansdotter (1867-1889).jpg|The victim, Hanna Johansdotter. Image:Yngsjö-murderer.jpg|Photograph taken just moments before the execution of Anna Månsdotter. The [[executioner]] [[Albert Gustaf Dahlman|Dahlman]] stands second to the left, hiding his axe behind his back. </gallery>

Kvällsposten, 16 juli 2007. Läst 3 mars 2009. *C. O. Bernhardsson: Brottets krönika (1954) *[[Bra Böckers Lexikon]], red. Jan-Öjvind Swahn, 3:e upplagan, band 22, Bokförlaget Bra Böcker, Höganäs 1991 sid. 193 *Nationalencyklopedin
